title: Farming Matters: Forcing Belgian Endive and Treviso Radicchio in The Upper Midwest with Peter Skold

tasks.task: Preparing and growing forcing chicories (endive and radicchio)
subtasks: Seeding the crops in mid-summer or early July
Managing weeds and watering during growth
Digging up the roots and storing them in a walk-in cooler
Selecting and trimming the roots for forcing
Preparing bulb crates for storing the roots in the dark forcing chamber
Monitoring and maintaining the appropriate humidity and temperature in the forcing chamber
Harvesting the forced crops after 3-6 weeks
Cleaning and packaging the endive and radicchio for sale
Exploring marketing opportunities for the specialty products in the winter market
Considering alternative uses for root scraps, such as livestock feed or coffee substitute

tasks.task: Applying for and managing a SARE grant for the project
subtasks: Writing a project proposal for SARE funding
Adapting to project delays due to the pandemic
Utilizing existing farm infrastructure (e.g., walk-in cooler) for the process
Customizing equipment (e.g., galvanized steel tanks) for the project
Learning and refining root trimming techniques to optimize product shape and quality

tasks.task: Contributing to farmer education and community through presentations
subtasks: Sharing project experiences and lessons learned with fellow farmers
Highlighting the value of diversifying winter crops and extending the growing season
Demonstrating the potential for specialty crops in niche markets
Encouraging customer education and tasting for new products

tasks.task: Seasonal farm operations involving winter crop cultivation
subtasks: Adapting conventional lettuce-growing practices to chicory cultivation
Using an undercutter bar for root harvest
Monitoring root health during storage and transfer phases
Addressing common challenges (e.g., light exposure leading to photosynthesis)
Adapting spacing for efficient planting and harvesting, e.g., direct seeding, transplanting, and proper root splay
Trimming endive roots to preserve the growth tip for tight heads
Direct seeding Belgian endive for straight taproots versus transplanting for radicchio's splay root structure

tasks.task: Developing customer relations for specialty winter crops
subtasks: Engaging with restaurant owners and chefs for product placement
Utilizing farmers markets and specialty groceries for direct sales
Educating customers on the unique flavors and preparation of endive and radicchio
